Dialogue.content: Hi, I'm Ethan Chen. This is my first time here.
Hello, Ethan! It's great to meet you. How are you feeling as you start your senior year?
I'm a bit anxious, actually. There's a lot of pressure with graduate applications coming up.
That makes sense. Senior year can be stressful. What specifically is weighing on your mind right now?
I feel overwhelmed with the need to secure strong recommendations and to present myself well. My mom has high expectations for me.
It sounds like there are a lot of expectations being placed on you. How does that affect your feelings about your future?
It's making me feel insecure about whether I can truly meet those expectations. I keep questioning if I'm good enough.
Those feelings are valid, Ethan. Many students experience this pressure. Have you thought about how you might cope with these feelings?
Maybe I could try breaking down the application process into smaller, manageable steps.
That sounds like a great idea! Setting smaller goals can help reduce feelings of being overwhelmed. How do you feel about starting that approach?
That makes me feel a little better. Thank you for the suggestion!
You're welcome! Remember, I'm here for you whenever you need support. Let's take it one step at a time together.
Hi, I'm back. I went to a leadership event, and it didn't go as planned.
Welcome back, Ethan! I'm here to listen. What happened at the leadership event?
I was supposed to speak, but I stumbled over my words and couldn't get my point across.
That sounds really tough. How did that make you feel in the moment and afterward?
I felt embarrassed and frustrated. I overheard my peers discussing their accomplishments, and it just made me feel more inadequate.
It's natural to feel discouraged when you're comparing yourself to others. Did you reach out to anyone afterward for support?
No, I didn't want to burden anyone with my feelings of failure.
It's common to feel like you're burdening others, but talking about your feelings can help. What do you think about reaching out to a friend?
I guess talking might help, even if it's just a little. I just wish I could erase that feeling of inadequacy.
It's okay to have those feelings, and expressing them can sometimes lessen their intensity. How do you feel about setting a goal to share your feelings with a friend next week?
Hi, I wanted to talk about my experiences volunteering at a community center.
Hi Ethan! I'm glad you're here to share. How was your volunteering experience?
It was eye-opening, but I also felt overwhelmed. I met youth who are really engaged in advocacy, and it left me questioning my own contributions.
That sounds impactful but also challenging. How did that affect you emotionally?
Instead of feeling motivated, I ended up feeling discouraged and unsure of my value in this field.
It's common to feel that way when you're comparing yourself to those with more experience. What might help you focus on your strengths instead?
I could remind myself that everyone has to start somewhere. I have my own experiences and passions that matter too.
Exactly! Reflecting on your unique contributions can help you feel more confident. What small action could you take to celebrate your progress?
Maybe I could write down some of my achievements or volunteer experiences to remind myself of the impact I've made.
Hi, I'm back. I talked to my sister Mai about my feelings of inadequacy.
Hi Ethan! I'm glad you're here again. How did that conversation go?
It went well. I shared my worries, and she suggested I seek mentorship opportunities in my field.
That's a great suggestion! Mentorship can provide valuable guidance. How do you feel about reaching out for that kind of support?
I think it's a good idea, but I'm still hesitant. What if I'm seen as inexperienced?
It's normal to feel nervous, but remember that mentors are there to help you grow. What can you do to support yourself in that decision?
I could remind myself that everyone has to learn and grow. Maybe I could write out what I want to gain from a mentor.
That's a strong approach! It can help clarify your expectations and make the conversation feel more structured. Are you ready to explore mentorship further?
